history.content:
No, you're fine.

"I'm concerned because this feels like a very extreme thing to do (I've never met anyone taking only 2 classes as a full-time student)" wow you need to meet more people! :)

children.subject: yep plenty of people take 2 techs a semester! 4 years is really more than enough to explore and take the classes you want to take.

don't worry!! the eecs/cs degree program is pretty light relative to other majors, in that it's possible to take fewer classes a semester and spread things out more/graduate early. take care of yourself and don't burn out :)

"wow you need to meet more people! :)" haha that may be true...to clarify though, I'm talking about taking 2 classes total, not just 2 technicals, since I feel like most people I've met at least take an interesting breadth class as their 3rd class. Also a lot of majors outside of CS also can't graduate on time with 2 classes per semester, so I guess I just felt guilty or that I might be missing something

Hey! The situation you are in right now is what I felt last year. It's definitely tough to keep up three techs, research, TAing, and everything else, so naturally, staying healthy goes out the door.

I fully recognize your concern with grad school and missing out on classes, because I struggled with the same question. I decided to ignore those concerns, take two techs, and focus on my wellbeing, and I have no regrets. If you're doing well academically but can't take care of yourself, are you really doing well? My opinion is no. I've been taking two techs a semester for the past two semesters, and it's honestly the greatest thing I've ever done. I feel much better, I'm staying healthy, and still earning a lot. Hope this helps!

There's nothing wrong with taking *only* 2 techs a semester! In fact, I spent my junior fall taking zero computer science technicals, and instead took breadths and interesting classes. I'll find out by the end of March whether this affected my graduate school admissions chances, but I really doubt it did. Take care of yourself first and foremost to avoid any issues getting worse.

history.content:
I'm currently enrolled in 3 technicals this semester, but I'm considering dropping one of them. If I do this, I would only be in 2 classes and would get the remaining units P/NP through TAing and research. My reasoning for this is that in the past, when taking 3 or more classes in addition to outside commitments, I did well academically but wasn't able to take care of myself health-wise or dedicate as much time to extracurriculars as I hoped to. With just 2 classes, I would probably have a significantly easier semester and be able to dedicate more time to research as well.

However, I'm concerned because this feels like a very extreme thing to do (I've never met anyone taking only 2 classes as a full-time student), and I'm not sure if this would reflect poorly on grad school applications if I choose to pursue that path in the future. I'm also worried that I will regret missing out on important classes at Berkeley, since there are so many great options and I can't possibly take them all.

Has anyone been in a similar situation before? Any advice on whether it would be better to only take 2 classes and dedicate more time to research, or to just stick with 3 technicals at the risk of lower grades and possibly not being able to spend as much time on research?

(FWIW, I've already taken or am taking the foundational classes for my area of AI research, i.e. 188/189/182/126/127, and I have 3 semesters left, so any additional classes would likely be to strengthen my math/EE skills or specialize in a particular area)
history.subject: Does taking a lower course load affect grad school admissions?
